0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• safety and efficacy have only been demonstrated in women with a prior spontaneous singleton preterm birth
  • not to be used in women with multiple gestations or other risk factors for preterm birth
  • Preterm labor, singleton pregnancy; Prophylaxis: 250 mg IM once weekly (every 7 days) starting between 16 weeks, 0 days and 20 weeks, 6 days of gestation; continue until week 37 (through 36 weeks, 6 days) of gestation or delivery

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• safety and effectiveness have not been demonstrated in pediatric patients younger than 16 years.
  • safety and efficacy have only been demonstrated in women with a prior spontaneous singleton preterm birth
  • not to be used in women with multiple gestations or other risk factors for preterm birth

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Preterm labor, singleton pregnancy; Prophylaxis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Amenorrhea
  • Endometrial carcinoma
  • Estrogen measurement, Endogenous; Diagnosis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• breast cancer or other estrogen or progestin-sensitive cancer, known, suspected, or history of
  • hepatic disease
  • hepatic tumors, benign or malignant
  • hypertension, uncontrolled
  • pregnancy-related cholestasis
  • thrombosis or thromboembolic disorder, current or past history
  • vaginal bleeding, undiagnosed, abnormal (not related to pregnancy

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• allergic reactions, including angioedema; have been reported; discontinue if necessary
  • arterial or deep venous thrombotic or thromboembolic events may occur; discontinue use
  • depression; risk of exacerbation; discontinue if serious recurrence
  • decreased glucose tolerance may occur (including prediabetic women)
  • fluid retention may occur
  • hypertension may occur; discontinue if necessary
  • jaundice may occur; discontinue if necessary
  • report suspected adverse reactions to Ther-Rx Corporation at 1-877-567-7676 or US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch.

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Hydroxyprogesterone: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site pain (34.8%), Injection site pruritus (5.8%), Injection site reaction (4.5%), Pruritus (7.7%), Swelling at injection site (17.1%), Urticaria (12.3%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (2.3%), Nausea (5.8%)
Serious
Hematologic:Thromboembolic disorder

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Hydroxyprogesterone caproate is a synthetic progestin. The mechanism by which it decreases the risk of recurrent preterm birth is unknown.

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono: Protein binding, albumin and corticosteroid binding globulins: extensive

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono: Hepatic: extensive via CYP3A4- and CYP3A5-mediated reduction, hydroxylation, and conjugation reactions

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Fecal: 50% (free steroids and conjugated metabolites)
  • Renal: 30% (free steroids and conjugated metabolites)

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• delivery at or beyond 37 weeks gestation is indicative of efficacy
  • glucose tolerance in prediabetic and diabetic women
  • fluid retention in patients with conditions which may be adversely influenced (eg, preeclampsia, epilepsy, migraine, asthma, or cardiac or renal dysfunction)
  • signs and symptoms of depression in patients with a history of depression

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
PROGESTINS
OVERDOSE: Rarely do acute ingestions result in obvious clinical manifestations. CHRONIC: Most adverse effects are related to chronic or high-dose therapy. Headache, dizziness, irregular menses, mastalgia, bloating, depression, decreased libido, cholestatic jaundice, hepatitis, oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea and thromboembolism may occur with chronic therapy.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
PROGESTINS
  • Support: Single acute overdoses will seldom result in toxicity. Supportive treatment is adequate in most situations.
  • Decontamination: Gastric decontamination is probably only necessary after very large ingestions or with toxic coingestants; administer activated charcoal in these cases.
  • Monitoring of patient: CHRONIC TOXICITY: Discontinue medication and monitor for signs of toxicity and treat symptomatically. Obtain a baseline CBC and hepatic and renal function tests in symptomatic patients.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
PROGESTINS
Toxicity is unlikely following an acute overdose. There are insufficient data reported in the literature to assess the range of toxicity in terms of mg/kg ingested.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of thrombotic or thromboembolic events (eg, DVT, stroke) or jaundice.
  • Drug may cause fluid retention, pruritus, urticaria, nausea, or diarrhea.
  • Advise patient with diabetes or prediabetes to report worsening glycemic control as drug may cause decreased glucose tolerance.
  • Counsel patient with a history of clinical depression that drug may cause a recurrence and to seek medical help.
  • Tell patient to report swelling, oozing of blood or fluid, or increasing pain at the injection site.
